entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued April 4 at 1:04PM PDT until April 5 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow expected. Total snow accumulations of up to 10 inches above 6000 feet, 3 to 6 inches from 5000 to 6000 feet, and up to 3 inches above 3000 feet. Winds gusting as high as 45 mph.
* WHERE...Western San Gabriel Mountains and Highway 14 Corridor and Eastern San Gabriel Mountains.
* WHEN...From 5 PM this afternoon to 11 PM PDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult to impossible.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Western San Gabriel Mountains and Highway 14 Corridor; Eastern San Gabriel Mountains

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 4 at 1:54PM MDT until April 10 at 12:00PM MDT by NWS Boise ID
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Oregon...
Owyhee River Below Owyhee Dam affecting Malheur County.
.A combination of heavy rain and snow melt will result in increased outflows from Owyhee Dam. Flows in rivers will increase quickly and reach minor flood stage.
For the Owyhee River...including Owyhee Dam...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Owyhee River below Owyhee Dam.
* WHEN...Until early Wednesday afternoon.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1:30 PM MDT Thursday /12:30 PM PDT Thursday/ the flow was 1,785.0 cfs. - Bankfull is 1000 cfs. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage late this afternoon to a crest of 5,000 cfs this evening. - Flood flow is 3,000 cfs. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 5,110 cfs on 05/31/2019. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Malheur, OR

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued April 4 at 1:51PM MDT until April 5 at 9:00PM MDT by NWS Denver CO
entry.summary:
The National Weather Service in Denver has issued a Red Flag Warning for wind and low relative humidity, which is in effect from 10 AM to 9 PM MDT Friday. The Fire Weather Watch is no longer in effect.
* Affected Area...Fire Weather Zones 242, 243 and 248.
* Timing...Late Friday morning through early Friday evening.
* Winds...South 20 to 30 mph with gusts up to 45 mph.
* Relative Humidity...As low as 9 percent.
* Impacts...Conditions will be favorable for rapid fire spread. Avoid outdoor burning and any activity that may produce a spark and start a wildfire.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northeast Weld County; Central and South Weld County; Logan County

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 4 at 3:46PM EDT by NWS Burlington VT
entry.summary:
Recent heavy snowfall combined with the pre-existing state of the snowpack has created the potential for avalanches in the back country of the Green Mountains near Smugglers Notch in Vermont and the High Peaks of the northern Adirondacks in New York.
Outdoor enthusiasts heading into the back country on Friday to snowshoe or ski, need to be aware of the avalanche danger, the risks involved and take the appropriate precautions.
Avoid avalanche prone areas such as steep, unstable slopes or downslope areas from vulnerable locations. If skiing, hiking, or snowshoeing stay on marked trails and avoid exposed open slopes.
Monitor announcements from local or state officials about the possible risk of avalanche and stay tuned to the latest National Weather Service forecasts and statements.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Western Essex; Lamoille; Eastern Chittenden

cap:parameter.value: INCREASED RISK FOR AVALANCHES ON FRIDAY

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued April 4 at 2:40PM CDT until April 5 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS Bismarck ND
entry.summary:
...FIRE WEATHER WATCH FOR PARTS OF NORTHERN AND CENTRAL NORTH DAKOTA FRIDAY AFTERNOON INTO FRIDAY EVENING...
.Critical fire weather conditions are possible on Friday afternoon into Friday evening across parts of northern and central North Dakota. Minimum relative humidity is expected to drop into the 18 to 25 percent range, with the lowest values in north central North Dakota. Southeast winds will be sustained from 25 to 30 mph, with gusts to 45 mph.
The National Weather Service in Bismarck has issued a Fire Weather Watch for wind and low relative humidity, which is in effect from Friday afternoon into Friday evening.
* WINDS...Southeast 25 to 30 mph with gusts up to 45 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 18 percent.
* AFFECTED AREA...Parts of northern and central North Dakota.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that ignite will spread rapidly and become difficult to control or suppress.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Burke; Renville; Bottineau; Rolette; Mountrail; Ward; McHenry; Pierce; McLean; Sheridan; Wells; Burleigh; Kidder

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 4 at 3:34PM EDT until April 7 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Mount Holly NJ
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in New Jersey...
Passaic River Above Singac affecting Passaic, Morris and Essex Counties.
For the Passaic River...including Singac...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Passaic River above Singac.
* WHEN...Until Sunday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 8.5 feet, Portions of the Wayne Town Center parking lot begin to flood. Hobson Avenue and Riverlawn Drive in Wayne begin to flood. Fairfield Road, Fayette Avenue, and Riversedge Road in Wayne can flood as water backs up the Pompton River. Lincoln Boulevard in Lincoln Park can also flood due to backwater up the Pompton river. The Pequannock River Park also floods. At 9.0 feet, Two Bridges Road in Fairfield is subject to closures. At 9.5 feet, Camp Lane and Marginal Road in Fairfield begins to flood. At 10.0 feet, Two Bridges Road in Fairfield begins to flood. Finns Drive, Siesta Drive, and Market street in Wayne are all susceptible to flooding. William Street, Louis Street, and Zeliff Avenue in Little Falls can begin to flood. Portions of Lincoln Park become impassable. The Meadows Golf Club in Lincoln Park floods.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 2:45 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 8.6 feet and rising. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 2:45 PM EDT Thursday was 8.6 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 9.4 feet tomorrow morning. It will then fall below flood stage early Sunday morning. - Flood stage is 8.5 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 9.4 feet on 12/23/2018. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Essex, NJ; Morris, NJ; Passaic, NJ

At 38.0 feet, Navigation suspended, lock out of service. At 39.0 feet, The well house and pump are flooded at the Fairway River Links Golf Course in Rayland Ohio.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:00 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 41.9 feet. - Bankfull stage is 37.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 3:00 PM EDT Thursday was 41.9 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 42.9 feet this evening. It will then fall below flood stage tomorrow evening. - Flood stage is 37.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 43.0 feet on 01/07/2005. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Connecticut...
Connecticut River At Middle Haddam affecting Middlesex County.
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Massachusetts...Rhode Island...Connecticut...
Charles River At Dover affecting Norfolk and Middlesex Counties.
Pawtuxet River At Cranston affecting Providence and Kent Counties.
Pawcatuck River At Wood River Junction affecting Washington County.
Pawcatuck River At Westerly affecting New London and Washington Counties.
Taunton River Near Bridgewater affecting Plymouth and Bristol Counties.
Wood River At Hope Valley affecting Washington County.
For the Charles River...including Dover...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Pawtuxet River...including Scituate Reservoir, Cranston... Moderate flooding is forecast. For the Pawcatuck River...including Wood River Junction, Westerly... Minor flooding is forecast. For the Taunton River...including Bridgewater...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Wood River...including Hope Valley...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Taunton River near Bridgewater.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 9.0 feet, Backwater flooding from the Taunton River will cause flooding of lower Purchade Brook in Middleboro. This will cause Woloski Park to become impassable by most vehicles for an extended period of time. Beware of the dangers of crossing flooded roadways. The water may be deeper than you think. Floodwaters have the ability to damage roadways. Heed the advice of local officials, and evacuate if asked to do so.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 2:45 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 8.0 feet. - Bankfull stage is 8.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 2:45 PM EDT Thursday was 8.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 9.1 feet early tomorrow afternoon. - Flood stage is 8.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Bristol, MA; Plymouth, MA

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 4 at 3:06PM EDT by NWS Jackson KY
entry.summary:
Mixed rain and snow showers in the lower elevations and snow showers above 2500 feet will impact the area tonight into late Friday morning. Above 2500 feet on Pine Mountain and Black Mountain, some light accumulations of a dusting to around an inch are forecast, generally on grassy and elevated surfaces. However, during the heavier snow showers, some roadways above 2500 feet could become snow- or slush-covered for a time, with this most probable on roadways above 3000 feet that cross Black Mountain in Harlan County such as KY 179 and KY 160. Other roadways that may be affected by winter travel include US 119, US 421, KY 38, KY 2010, and the Little Shepherd Trail.
If traveling across Pine and Black Mountains tonight through Friday morning, expect some slick spots. Slow down and allow extra time to reach your destination.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Harlan; Letcher

cap:parameter.value: Minor Snow Accumulations Possible Above 2500 Feet Tonight Through Friday Morning

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued April 4 at 2:05PM CDT until April 5 at 8:00PM CDT by NWS Dodge City KS
entry.summary:
...Critical Wildfire Danger Friday Afternoon...
The National Weather Service in Dodge City has issued a Red Flag Warning for wind and low relative humidity, which is in effect from noon CDT /noon MDT/ to 8 PM CDT /8 PM MDT/ Friday. A Fire Weather Watch has also been issued. This Fire Weather Watch for wind and low relative humidity is in effect from Saturday afternoon through Saturday evening. The Fire Weather Watch is no longer in effect.
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zone 061 Hamilton, Fire Weather Zone 062 Kearny, Fire Weather Zone 074 Stanton, Fire Weather Zone 075 Grant, Fire Weather Zone 076 Haskell, Fire Weather Zone 084 Morton, Fire Weather Zone 085 Stevens and Fire Weather Zone 086 Seward.
* WINDS...South 35 to 45 mph with gusts up to 60 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 11 percent.
* IMPACTS...Any ignitions will have the potential to burn out of control and exhibit extreme wildfire behavior.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Hamilton; Kearny; Stanton; Grant; Haskell; Morton; Stevens; Seward

entry.summary:
Sustained winds of 10 to 20 mph, with gusts as high as 30 mph are expected across portions of northwest North Carolina through late afternoon. Meanwhile, relative humidity values around 30 percent are expected across the piedmont. These conditions combined with dry vegetation will enhance the potential for the start and spread of wildfires across the area.
Please refer to your local burn permitting authorities on whether you can burn today. If you do burn, use extreme caution since fires can quickly get out of hand under these conditions.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Surry; Stokes; Rockingham; Caswell; Yadkin

cap:parameter.value: INCREASED FIRE DANGER IN EFFECT THROUGH EARLY EVENING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 4 at 1:17PM EDT by NWS Raleigh NC
entry.summary:
Increased fire danger will continue across the most of the northern and western North Carolina Piedmont from through 8 PM. Westerly winds will gust between 25 and 35 mph, and along with low relative humidity around 25 percent and dry fuels, increased fire danger is expected.
Refer to your local burn-permitting authority on whether you may burn. If you do burn, exercise extreme caution.

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued April 4 at 9:17AM PDT until April 6 at 3:00PM PDT by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Large breaking waves of 4 to 7 feet with local sets to 8 feet, and dangerous rip currents. Surf will be highest tonight through Friday on southwest and west-facing coasts. Minor tidal overflow around Friday morning high tide will be possible for southwest and west-facing coasts.
* WHERE...Santa Barbara County Southwestern Coast and Santa Barbara County Southeastern Coast.
* WHEN...From 9 PM this evening to 3 PM PDT Saturday.
* IMPACTS...There is an increased risk of ocean drowning. Rip currents can pull swimmers and surfers out to sea. Waves can wash people off beaches and rocks, and capsize small boats nearshore. Very minor coastal flooding may occur around Friday morning high tide between 7AM and 8AM.

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued April 4 at 10:56AM EDT until April 4 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents, large breaking waves expected, and strong longshore currents in the surf zone.
* WHERE...The beaches from Cape Hatteras to Surf City.
* WHEN...From 8 AM EDT this morning through this evening.
* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water. Dangerous shore break can throw a swimmer or surfer head first into the bottom causing neck and back injuries. Strong longshore currents will create dangerous swimming conditions.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The most likely time for strong rip currents to occur is a couple hours either side of low tide, which will occur around 11 AM Thursday.

* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Ohio River at Pittsburgh.
* WHEN...Until late this evening.
* IMPACTS...At 18.0 feet, Water begins to flow onto the Monongahela Parking Wharf. At 19.0 feet, Water begins to flow onto the North Shore riverwalk between the stadiums. At 19.5 feet, The Monongahela Parking Wharf is completely flooded. At 20.0 feet, Water is up to one foot deep in the lower areas of the North Shore Riverwalk. At 22.0 feet, The Tenth Street Bypass floods. At 22.5 feet, The fountain plaza is flooded. At 24.0 feet, Water enters the outer pool of the fountain. At 24.9 feet, Water enters the inner pool of the fountain. At 25.0 feet, The Parkway Central (also known as the bathtub) is closed by flooding. Lower North Side businesses are affected. At 26.0 feet, State Correctional Institution Pittsburgh is impacted. At 27.6 feet, The fountain in Point State Park is completely submerged. At 28.0 feet, Pumping operations begin on Neville Island. The Wood Street T station facilities are impacted. Fort Pitt Boulevard is closed. At 29.0 feet, River Avenue on the North Side begins to flood. At 30.0 feet, 200 manufacturing concerns and companies in Pittsburgh are affected by flooding. Acrisure Stadium playing field is flooded. Point state park is flooded to the Portal Bridge.

Little Stillwater Creek will flood most of Phac Park along with portions of Wilson Road in Dennison. At 12.9 feet, Numerous low land areas are flooded. At 13.3 feet, Flood waters reach Newport Avenue in Uhrichsville as well as East 12th Street and North Main Street half way to East 11th Street. Phac Park along Little Stillwater Creek in Dennison is flooded. At 17.8 feet, Flooding occurs in the west and north side of Uhrichsville (Main Street, West 5th Street, the east end of 4th Street, and the east end of Franklin Street.) Also flooded are areas in Uhrichsville and Dennison along Little Stillwater Creek and the west end of Newport.

.Runoff from the heavy rainfall over the past 72 hours is resulting in many locations reaching or exceeding flood stage.
Rivers are forecast to begin falling within the next 24 to 36 hours.
* WHAT...Major flooding is occurring and major flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Wills Creek at Cambridge.
* WHEN...Until late Sunday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 15.0 feet, Overflowing of poor drainage and low lying areas will result in minor flooding along wills creek. At 16.0 feet, Basement flooding begins through floor drains and other sewer connections. Local interruptions in sanitary service may occur along Gordon's Run from 3rd Street to 6th Street. At 17.0 feet, Water overflows wills Creek Valley Road to a depth of 2 feet. Water reaches a depth of 1 foot on North Eighth Street. At 18.0 feet, Flood waters begin effecting apartments along Wills Creek Valley Road. Southgate Parkway will also begin flooding near Woodlawn Avenue. At 20.0 feet, Flood waters reach residential areas on the west side of Cambridge. At 22.0 feet, The North 8th Street Bridge near the school campus is impassable. Flood waters reach Wills Creek Valley Drive near the County Road 35 Bridge. The north side of Cambridge is close to being cut off from access. Water from Wills Creek will flood the west end of Cambridge. At 23.0 feet, Flood waters are expected to reach the Cambridge Square Plaza on Route 209. South 10th Street and Orchard Avenue should also begin to feel the effects of the rising waters. Seek higher ground and do not attempt to cross flooded roadways.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:15 AM EDT Thursday the stage was 21.2 feet. - Bankfull stage is 13.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 9:15 AM EDT Thursday was 21.3 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage early Sunday morning and continue falling to 10.9 feet Monday evening. - Flood stage is 15.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 19.3 feet on 01/13/2005. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Guernsey, OH

entry.summary:
Sustained winds of 10 to 20 mph, with gusts as high as 30 mph are expected across portions of northwest North Carolina today. Meanwhile, relative humidity values around 30 percent are expected across the piedmont. These conditions combined with dry vegetation will enhance the potential for the start and spread of wildfires across the area.
Please refer to your local burn permitting authorities on whether you can burn today. If you do burn, use extreme caution since fires can quickly get out of hand under these conditions.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 4 at 9:40AM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
Santa Fe River At Three Rivers Estates affecting Gilchrist, Suwannee and Columbia Counties.
Additional information is available at https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/forecasts.php?wfo=jax.
The next statement will be issued Friday morning at 945 AM EDT.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Santa Fe River at Three Rivers Estates.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 16.0 feet, Lowland flooding begins on SW Santa Fe Drive south of Santa Fe Road in Columbia County. At 16.3 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission begins enforcement of a no wake zone on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream of the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to the confluence with the Suwannee River and on the Ichetucknee River upstream to the US 27 bridge. At 17.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences on Santa Fe Road in Columbia County and on River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.0 feet, Water begins to flood River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.8 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission expands the no wake zone restriction further upstream on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream on the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to one-half mile upstream of the State Road 47 bridge. At 19.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences along the Ichetucknee River. At 19.8 feet, Waters begins to affect homes in the Hollingsworth Bluff area at State Route 47. At 20.0 feet, Access to homes on Santa Fe Road below SW Riverside Avenue becomes restricted in Columbia. Flooding begins on Santa Fe and Wilson Springs Road.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:00 AM EDT Thursday the stage was 17.3 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to 18.3 feet Tuesday morning. Additional rises are possible thereafter. - Flood stage is 17.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

.A strong high pressure system will remain north of the Hawaiian Islands today. Strong and gusty easterly trade winds will exceed wind advisory thresholds in windier areas across the state. Portions of the advisory area may need to be extended into Friday.

* WHERE...Portions of all Hawaiian Islands.

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued April 4 at 4:24AM MDT until April 6 at 8:00PM MDT by NWS El Paso Tx/Santa Teresa NM
entry.summary:
...CRITICAL FIRE WEATHER CONDITIONS MAY DEVELOP SATURDAY AFTERNOON...
.A combination of increasing west/northwest winds, low relative humidity, and continued drying of fine fuels will potentially produce critical fire weather conditions over most of the lowlands east of Deming.
The National Weather Service in El Paso Tx/Santa Teresa has issued a Fire Weather Watch for gusty winds and low humidity, which is in effect from Saturday afternoon through early Saturday evening.
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zone 055 Texas Fire Weather Zone 055 El Paso County, Fire Weather Zone 056 Texas Fire Weather Zone 056 Hudspeth County and Fire Weather Zone 112 South Central Lowlands and Southern Rio Grande Valley/BLM/GLZ.
* TIMING...Beginning late Saturday morning into early Saturday evening.
* WINDS...West 25 to 35 mph with gusts up to 50 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...From 11 to 14 percent.
* TEMPERATURES...From the upper 50s to mid 60s.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.
entry.cap:areaDesc: South Central Lowlands And Southern Rio Grande Valley; El Paso; Hudspeth

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 4 at 4:22AM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
entry.summary:
Sustained winds of 10 to 20 mph, with gusts as high as 30 mph are expected across northeast Georgia this afternoon. Meanwhile, relative humidity of 25 to 30 percent is expected across the Piedmont. These conditions combined with dry vegetation will enhance the potential for the start and spread of wildfires across the area.
Please refer to your local burn permitting authorities on whether you can burn today. If you do burn, use extreme caution since fires can quickly get out of hand under these conditions.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Rabun; Habersham; Stephens; Franklin; Hart; Elbert

cap:parameter.value: INCREASED FIRE DANGER IN EFFECT FROM NOON EDT TODAY THROUGH THIS EVENING

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued April 4 at 4:10AM EDT until April 4 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Gray ME
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow and sleet. Additional snow accumulations between 5 and 11 inches for a storm total of 6 to 17 inches and sleet accumulations around one third of an inch. Winds gusting as high as 55 mph.
* WHERE...Portions of south central and southwest Maine and central and southern New Hampshire.
* WHEN...Until 8 PM EDT this evening.
* IMPACTS...Moderate snow with periods of heavy snow with potential for a foot plus of accumulation will create hazardous travel conditions across the region. Strong, gusty winds are also expected with the snowstorm, which could cause damage to trees and power lines. Travel is not recommended as heavy snowfall and very low visibility will create extremely dangerous driving conditions. The hazardous conditions will impact the morning commute, with impacts potentially lingering into the evening commute.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...This is a long-duration, multi-faceted event. Intensity will continue increase this morning when some of the heaviest rates may fall accompanied by strong, gusty winds. Be prepared for a prolonged duration of impact. Very strong downslope winds west of the White Mountains are expected late tonight and Thursday morning.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coastal York; Coastal Cumberland; Sagadahoc; Lincoln; Knox; Coastal Waldo; Sullivan; Merrimack; Cheshire; Eastern Hillsborough; Interior Rockingham; Coastal Rockingham; Western And Central Hillsborough

entry.summary:
Relative Humidities of 25 percent or less can be expected for 4 or more hours this afternoon into the evening. Winds will be west and then northwest at 10 to 15 MPH and gusty.
With dry fuels, high fire danger conditions can be expected.
Please refer to your local burn permitting authorities whether you may burn outdoors. If you do burn outside, use extreme caution.

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued April 4 at 1:14AM MDT until April 5 at 9:00PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT 11 AM TO 9 AM FRIDAY FOR THE NORTHWEST PLATEAU, RIO GRANDE VALLEY, SANDIA AND MANZANO MOUNTAINS BELOW SNOWPACK AND ALL OF EASTERN NEW MEXICO DUE TO STRONG WINDS, LOW HUMIDITY AND AN UNSTABLE ATMOSPHERE...
...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT SATURDAY AFTERNOON AND EARLY EVENING FOR THE MIDDLE RIO GRANDE VALLEY AND ALL OF EASTERN NEW MEXICO DUE TO STRONG WINDS AND LOW HUMIDITY...
.Widespread critical fire weather conditions are expected on Friday as winds increase ahead of an approaching storm system. These strong winds combined with low humidity will allow for rapid fire spread in dry and receptive fuels. Strong south to southwest winds will peak during the afternoon hours, but will remain elevated through the evening and overnight Friday night. A strong cold front will surge from west to east early Saturday. Very strong westerly winds will develop behind the front and with continued low humidity values, critical fire weather conditions are expected once again on Saturday for the Rio Grande Valley and all of eastern New Mexico.
The National Weather Service in Albuquerque has issued a Red Flag Warning...which is in effect from 11 AM to 9 PM MDT Friday. The Fire Weather Watch is no longer in effect.
* AREA AND TIMING...This includes the Northwest Plateau (Zone 101), Upper Rio Grande Valley and Lower Chama River Valley (Zone 121), and the Sandia and Manzano Mountains below snowpack (Zone 124) from late Friday morning through Friday evening.
* 20 FOOT WINDS...South to southwest 25 to 35 mph with gusts between 45 and 60 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...Minimum values between 10 and 15 percent.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northwest Plateau; Upper Rio Grande Valley and Lower Chama River Valley; Sandia and Manzano Mountains

cap:parameter.value: RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FROM 11 AM TO 9 PM MDT FRIDAY

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued April 3 at 4:58PM PDT by NWS San Diego CA
entry.summary:
The South Coast AQMD has issued an air quality alert due to increased particle pollution from blowing dust. The air quality alert is in effect 11 AM Thursday through 5 AM Friday.
In areas directly impacted by high levels of windblown dust, limit your exposure by remaining indoors with windows and doors closed and avoiding vigorous physical activity. Run your air conditioner or an air purifier. If temperatures allow, avoid using whole house fans or swamp coolers that bring in outside air.
Exposure to high particle pollution levels can cause serious health problems, including asthma attacks, heart and lung disease symptoms, and increased risk of respiratory infections. People with heart or lung diseases should follow their doctor's advice for dealing with episodes of unhealthy air quality. Children, older adults, and people with respiratory or heart disease should avoid prolonged exposure and strenuous activities when particle pollution levels are high.
To help minimize outdoor particle pollution levels: * Carpool, telecommute, reduce trips, or take public transportation * Slow down if driving on dirt roads * Stabilize loose soils
Levels of particle pollution can vary hour by hour and by location depending on wind conditions.
To view current and forecasted air quality levels, visit the South Coast Air Quality Management District website at aqmd.gov or download the mobile app at www.aqmd.gov/mobileapp. Additional details for this air quality alert may be available at www.aqmd.gov/advisory.
To view current and forecasted air quality levels, visit the Mojave Desert Air Quality Management District website at mdaqmd.ca.gov. Additional details for this air quality alert may be available at www.mdaqmd.ca.gov/advisories.
To view current and forecast air quality within Imperial County visit the Imperial County Air Quality website at http://www.imperialvalleyair.org/ or follow ICAPCD on Twitter, facebook or Instagram (@county_air).
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coachella Valley; San Gorgonio Pass Near Banning

cap:parameter.value: AIR QUALITY ALERT DUE TO ELEVATED PARTICLE POLLUTION LEVELS FROM WINDBLOWN DUST

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 3 at 1:06PM PDT by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
* A strong cold front is moving through the Sierra and western NV through Thursday, bringing gusty winds, much colder temperatures, and chances for snow showers.
* Gusty southwest winds will develop this afternoon north of Highway 50 and shift to the Eastern Sierra of Mono and Mineral counties overnight into Thursday morning. This will impact outdoor activities, produce bumpy airplane rides, and cause gusty cross winds for high-profile vehicles, especially along Highway 395, Highway 95, and I-580. Wind gusts along the Sierra crest will exceed 80 mph.
* Snow showers across northeast CA and the Sierra today will then push across the region through Friday. Roads will be slick in the Sierra, especially at night. The higher April sun angle will limit accumulations during the daytime hours. Prepare for possible delays if your plans include travel across the Sierra. Total snow accumulations: Above 7000 feet in Greater Lake Tahoe: greater than 6 inches on the west side of Lake Tahoe and 1 to 2 inches in the Carson Range. Above 7000 feet in Mono County: 3 to 12 inches with up to 18 inches along the highest Sierra crest. Below 7000 feet in Mono County: a trace up to 4 inches. Lowest Nevada valleys: light snow showers, but little or no accumulation.
* Unusually cold air for early April settles into the area with daytime temperatures 15-20 degrees below normal Thursday and Friday followed by only slight warming over the weekend. Hard freezes are almost a certainty each night, even for lower western NV valleys beginning Thursday night. Be ready to protect sensitive plants, wrap exposed irrigation systems, and watch out for vulnerable populations and pets.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Surprise Valley California; Lassen-Eastern Plumas-Eastern Sierra Counties; Greater Lake Tahoe Area; Mono; Mineral and Southern Lyon Counties; Greater Lake Tahoe Area; Greater Reno-Carson City-Minden Area; Western Nevada Basin and Range including Pyramid Lake; Northern Washoe County

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 3 at 12:28PM CDT until April 13 at 10:00AM CDT by NWS Paducah KY
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Paducah has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Indiana...Illinois...
Wabash River at New Harmony
.Runoff from recent heavy rain over the Ohio River Valley will cause minor flooding to develop along the Wabash River at New Harmony. The river is forecast to rise above flood stage Sunday morning and crest near 16.2 feet Wednesday, April 10.
For the Wabash River...including New Harmony...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Wabash River at New Harmony.
* WHEN...From late Saturday night to Saturday, April 13.
* IMPACTS...At 15.0 feet, The river overflows low ground on the Illinois side.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:30 AM CDT Wednesday the stage was 4.4 feet. - Bankfull stage is 12.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage early Sunday morning to a crest of 16.2 feet Wednesday, April 10. It will then fall below flood stage Saturday, April 13. - Flood stage is 15.0 feet.

entry.title: Avalanche Watch issued April 2 at 1:37PM EDT by NWS Gray ME
entry.summary:
AVAGYX
The following message is transmitted at the request of the Forest Service Mount Washington Avalanche Center, Gorham NH.
The US Forest Service Mount Washington Avalanche Center has issued a backcountry avalanche watch. This avalanche watch does not apply to operating ski areas.
* WHAT...A significant winter storm, bringing the possibility of 30+ inches of snow and strong wind to the higher summits in the Presidential Range, will create dangerous avalanche conditions.
* WHERE...The Presidential Range avalanche forecast area, including but not limited to Tuckerman Ravine, Huntington Ravine, Gulf of Slides, Great Gulf, King Ravine, Burt Ravine, Ammonoosuc Ravine, Oakes Gulf and steep, open terrain in the mountains that are bounded by US Rt 2, US Rt 302, and NH Rt 16. This includes hiking trails that traverse across steep terrain like Summer Lion Head trail. Similar avalanche danger may exist at locations outside of the coverage area where steep, open terrain exists that has collected drifted snow.
* WHEN...In effect from Tue 16:00 EDT to Fri 16:00 EDT.
* IMPACTS... Large, destructive avalanches are likely to occur naturally and spontaneously and will exist throughout steep terrain including hiking trails. These avalanches may be large enough to bury multiple people, do significant damage to trees or buildings, and will likely run far down in paths or areas that are normally safe zones. Precipitation rates are forecast to be heavy, with 1-2 inches of snow falling per hour at times and visibility limited.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Southern Coos
